Package io.crums.sldg

Class Path

java.lang.Object
io.crums.sldg.Path
All Implemented Interfaces:
io.crums.io.Serial, io.crums.util.hash.Digest
Direct Known Subclasses:
SkipPath, TargetPath
public class Path
extends java.lang.Object
implements io.crums.util.hash.Digest, io.crums.io.Serial
A list of connected rows in a SkipLedger with strictly ascending row numbers. This describes a hash proof that specified rows are indeed from the same ledger with strong constraints on the possible row numbers.

Validation Guarantee

Every instance's hash pointers are checked for validity at construction. Furthermore, every public constructor makes a defensive copy of its row inputs. The upshot of this guarantee is that a reference to an instance at runtime, is a reference to an immutable proof.

Performance Note

Instances are small objects. Self reminder: there's little point in optimization. Serialization footprint, maybe; clock-cycles NO(!).

Class Hierarchy Note

This base class knows about its subclasses via its Serial implementation. It's an anti-pattern, but one which centralizes factory methods for loading (which is why it knows about everyone). It could be refactored, but at the cost of complexity. Ultimately, the simpler wins--unless you find something simpler.

TODO

Some cleaning up to do, since the new classes allow better separation-of-concerns..

  1. The morsel design obviates the need to encapsulate beacons in this abstraction. Take it out.
  2. PathInfo obviates the need to keep track of targets. Remove this business of target rows. It's not needed anyway in with morsels.

    • beacons

      protected final java.util.List<io.crums.util.Tuple<java.lang.Long,​java.lang.Long>> beacons
      Possibly empyty, read-only list of beacon row numbers together with their minimum UTCs.
      • Tuple.a is the beacon row number: the row's entry hash is the beacon hash.
      • Tuple.b is the beacon's timestamp: the next row's age must be older than this.

      public java.util.List<Row> rows()

      non-empty list of rows with ascending row numbers, each successive row linked to the previous via one of the next row's hash pointers

    • intersects

      public final boolean intersects​(Path path)
      Determines if this instance and the given path have any equal rows. (2 rows are equal iff both their row numbers and row hashes match.)
      Returns:
      intersects(path, false)
      See Also:
      intersects(Path, boolean)

    • intersectsConsistently

      public final boolean intersectsConsistently​(Path path)
      Determines whether this rows intersects the other consistently. 2 paths intersect consistently if any of their covered row numbers intersect and if each pair of row hashes at those intersections are equal.
      Returns:
      intersects(path, true)
      See Also:
      intersects(Path, boolean)

    • intersects

      public final boolean intersects​(Path other, boolean consistent)
      Determines whether this path intersects the other. This is can have more restrictive semantics than a simple set intersection (see below). Regardless, it is always a symmetric relationship (the answer is the same if the roles of instance and argument are reversed).

      Terminology

      Let's introduce some terminology:

      1. Intersect. 2 paths intersect if the hash of any 2 rows in the ledger they describe cooincide at the same row number. But since our ledger rows reference previous rows thru their hash pointers, a path may intersect another path even if their row numbers don't intersect. (But note, their rowNumbersCovered() sets must intersect.)
      2. Intersect Consistently. 2 paths intersect consistently if (a) they intersect (as defined above) and (b) if any other covered row numbers in their respective paths intersect, then so too must their row hashes.

      So if 2 paths intersect consistently, then there exists a ledger that can produce them both; if 2 paths intersect, but don't intersect consistently, then no ledger exists that can produce them both.

      Parameters:
      other - non-null
      consistent - if true, the test determines a consistent intersection.

    • rowNumbers

      public final java.util.List<java.lang.Long> rowNumbers()
      Returns the row numbers in the rows, in the order they occur.
      Returns:
      non-empty, ascending list of row numbers ≥ 1

    • rowNumbersCovered

      public final java.util.SortedSet<java.lang.Long> rowNumbersCovered()
      Returns all the row numbers referenced in this path. This collection includes the path's row numbers as well other rows referenced thru the rows' skip pointers.

      The upshot of this accounting is that the hash of every row number returned is known by the instance.

      See Also:
      getRowHash(long)

    • getRowHash

      public final java.nio.ByteBuffer getRowHash​(long rowNumber) throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
      Returns the hash of the row with the given rowNumber. This is not just a convenience for getting the hash of one of the instance's rows; it also provides a more sophisticated algorithm so that it can return the hash of any row returned by rowNumbersCovered().
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if rowNumber is not a member of the set returned by rowNumbersCovered()

    • getRowOrReferringRow

      public final Row getRowOrReferringRow​(long rowNumber) throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
      Returns the row with lowest row-number that knows about the given rowNumber. I.e. if this path instance has a row with the given rowNumber then that row is returned. Otherwise, the first row that references the row with given row-number is returned.
      Returns:
      a row whose row number is ≥ rowNumber
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if rowNumber is not a member of the set returned by rowNumbersCovered()
      See Also:
      getRowHash(long)

    • subPath

      public final Path subPath​(long loRowNumber, long hiRowNumber)
      Returns a subpath view of this instance for the given hi and lo row numbers in this path instance. The returned instance is untargeted: that is the target of the returned instance is just the default first row.
      Parameters:
      loRowNumber - low row number
      hiRowNumber - high row number (inclusive!)
      Returns:
      an untargeted sub path
      See Also:
      isTargeted()

      public final boolean isAdjacent​(Path path)
      Determines whether this instance and the given path are adjacent to one another.

      This is a symmetric property.

    • serialSize

      public final int serialSize()

      The base class knows a lot about it's subclasses. This is because of the static load method. Which is why this method is marked final. It's because the base class is also a factory.

      Specified by:
      serialSize in interface io.crums.io.Serial
